2022 Narrative: SuccessesIn support of enhancing national and regional capacity for crime response management (CPD output 4.1), the long-awaited Police Records Management Information System (PRMIS) was operationalized to transition police stations from paper-based, inefficient case management to a fully digital, cloud-based platform that systematically manages the hundreds of data points gathered by police officers and allows the data to be aggregated and analysed in real-time. The launch of the platform, which marked the culmination of 5 years of collaborative work, was deployed in police stations in ANB, BRB, GRN, VCT and SKN. Of the 51 combined stations stations across these jurisdictions that have the necessary infrastructure to facilitate the system, 80% have fully onboarded the PRMIS platform and are relying on it for management of crime data. In ANB, 100% of stations had been operationalised by year-end. To support the effective utilisation for the data to make informed crime prevention decisions and to ultimately reduce the number of victims of intentional homicide (SP Outcome 3, Indicator 5), over 1,000 police officers were capacitated to undertake data collection and crime analysis, with more than 50 trained as trainers to support sustainability. This work contributed directly to the UNDP Strategic Plan Signature Solution Indicator 2.3.1.Challenges﻿In some jurisdictions, lack of ICT infrastructure within some police stations prevented the full deployment of the PRMIS system. While an initial assessment of the national capacity to roll-out the platform had been undertaken, it did not fully reflect the status at each individual police station and it was later recognised that some critical elements including internet connectivity remained a challenge and prevented more uptake of the digitalisation programme. As a result, some of the hardware deployed in previous periods was not fully utilised and it was not possible to operationalise PRMIS and in these instances the roll-out was delayed and could not be completed by year-end.
2023 Narrative: CARISECURE 2.0 (as at June 2023)The budget for 2023 was at the time entered, envisioned to focus on salaries, therefore the expenditure entered also reflects salaries. The project has achieved 5/6 country endorsements to date with Barbados outstanding due to political sensitivities around the Trafficking in Persons (TIP) objective. CS2.0 partnered with UWI to deliver a National Crime Symposium: From Research to Action: Focused Approaches to Crime Prevention – 25-26 May. With over 190 participants, strong youth participation and presentations on both CS1.0 and CS2.0 including the latest mapping and gap analysis presentations from CS2.0 consultant, the event created a strong partnership opportunity and facilitated a platform for national dialogue on data driven crime policies.  Consultants contracted to provide Mapping and Gap Analyses on youth and TIP, completed their reports during Q2 and this helped focused the projects next steps. Consultants focused on developing youth and TIP multi-year country workplans building on the Mapping and Gap Analyses work, were contracted and began work in Q2 with delivery concluding in Q3. Missions to Grenada and SVG were planned for early Q3 to formalize country workplans.  Consultations with the Media Institute of the Caribbean to support a media assessment on youth and crime and TIP in the project countries, has progressed with contracting due to take place in early Q3 and delivery of assessment and recommendations by end of Q3.  High-level agreement between BB MCO and TT MCO on joint delivery approach of CS2.0 in Trinidad and Tobago has significantly improved relationships and delivery arrangements. Trinidad has made significant progress on the design of the TT country work plan with approval due by BB MOC and USAID in early Q3. PACE Justice projectAs PACE justice is in the inception phase, the expenditure specific to that project was focused on salaries. To date, two (2) staff members have been onboarded. However the only activity to date has been the project launch, therefore expenditure has been limited.

2023 Narrative: UN WOMEN UPDATE:Almost one in three three women experience lifetime physical intimate partner violence (IPV)- (28% lifetime; 5% current), of which most (64%), experience a severe act of physical IPV at least once. According to the findings of the 2017 Trinidad and Tobago Women's Health Survey (WHS), 30% of ever-partnered women experienced physical and/or sexual violence by an intimate partner in their lifetime and 6% reported this was their experience 12 months prior to data collection.In light of the above and in keeping with its mandate, UN Women MCO Caribbean continued to support institutional strengthening, through the rollout of the Gender-responsive Policing Programme and scaled up GBV prevention programming, utilizing evidence-based approaches with the rollout of the Foundations Programme and the Partnership for Peace. Over 100 police officers were therefore trained to improve the gender-responsive administration of justice, and in victim and survivor-centered, trauma-informed policing.UN Women additionally provided support to the Judiciary of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago to design and implement a perpetrator rehabilitation programme based on the UN Women Foundations and Partnership for Peace Programmes and further disbursed approximately USD 100,000 worth of funding to 4 civil society organisations. Most of these were first time recipients of grants, and a large component of the grants were aimed at strengthening the technical, financial and operational capacity of civil society. Bolstering this through capacity building workshops, regional and intergenerational dialogues, and tailored coaching and training, civil society organisations working on ending violence against women and girls can now better plan, manage and report on their programmes and activities, as well as the delivery of essential services to victims and survivors of gender based violence.

2024 Narrative: In 2024, under the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime (UNTOC) and in line with UNODC’s Global Programme on Crimes that Affect the Environment, 15 Indigenous Peoples and/or Indigenous Peoples Collectives from the Amazon benefited from the Roadmap for Evaluation of Indigenous Territorial Protection Early Warning Systems and the Roadmap for Rapid Risk Assessment of Illegal Mining within Indigenous Territorial Protection. 30 people from 14 Indigenous Peoples or Associations and Collectives participated in the Course on Integral Protection of Indigenous Territories, held in partnership with the Amazon Environmental Research Institute (IPAM) and the Coordination of Indigenous Organizations of the Brazilian Amazon (COIAB) (https://tinyurl.com/2uu228m8). 2023 Narrative: L'ONUDC met en œuvre cette initiative en coopération avec l'Organisation des États américains, visant à renforcer les capacités de tous les acteurs de la chaîne pénale pour enquêter efficacement sur les crimes de corruption et de blanchiment d'argent.Une assistance technique sera fournie dans deux domaines interconnectés :• Lutte contre la corruption : Améliorer le développement institutionnel et renforcer les capacités nationales pour enquêter et poursuivre des affaires complexes de corruption impliquant des éléments financiers. Cela implique l'engagement et la participation de tous les acteurs dans l'enquête sur la corruption et les crimes économiques, y compris l'ULCC (Unité de Lutte Contre la Corruption), l'unité d'enquête de la PNH (Police Nationale d'Haïti) et le Parquet.• LBC/FT : Renforcer les autorités compétentes, avec un accent particulier sur les enquêteurs financiers de la PNH et de l'Unité Centrale de Renseignements Financiers (UCREF), les autorités judiciaires et le secteur privé pour mieux comprendre les risques liés au blanchiment d'argent et au financement du terrorisme, et pour détecter, enquêter et poursuivre les cas de blanchiment d'argent et de financement du terrorisme de manière plus efficace.Le projet a été initié par une mission d'évaluation dirigée par l'ONUDC en collaboration avec l'OEA et facilitée par le BINUH. Cette mission a marqué le début d'un effort global visant à renforcer les mesures de lutte contre la corruption et les enquêtes sur les crimes financiers dans le pays.Dans la phase initiale, l'ONUDC, tirant parti de son vaste expérience du Mécanisme d'Examen de l'Application de la CNUCC et des premiers engagements avec le pouvoir judiciaire et les principaux organes de lutte contre la corruption, a réalisé une évaluation approfondie du système de justice pénale. Cette évaluation a identifié des lacunes spécifiques et des besoins en expertise parmi les juges haïtiens, les procureurs, la police et le personnel des organes spécialisés dans les enquêtes sur la corruption et les finances.En réponse à ces constats, l'ONUDC, en partenariat avec le PNUD, a élaboré un manuel d'introduction à la lutte contre la corruption adapté aux juges et aux officiers de police judiciaire. Ce manuel vise à établir une base de connaissances fondamentale. S'appuyant sur cette initiative, l'ONUDC a commencé à développer des outils plus complets, y compris un programme de formation détaillé sur la lutte contre la corruption et les crimes financiers, ainsi que des directives sur la conduite éthique et l'intégrité pour les professionnels du droit, mettant en avant leur rôle dans la lutte contre la corruption, qui doivent être finalisés en 2024.De plus, l'ONUDC a lancé l'évaluation des procédures internes de l'ULCC, avec une méthodologie partagée et approuvée par les homologues nationaux. Cette évaluation devrait être achevée en 2024.En outre, l'ONUDC et l'OEA ont fait des progrès significatifs dans la promotion de la coopération internationale pour soutenir les autorités haïtiennes dans leur lutte contre la corruption et les crimes financiers. Cela inclut la facilitation de l'adhésion à des réseaux internationaux tels que GLOBE et la facilitation de l'établissement de coopérations internationales avec plusieurs États, renforçant ainsi le cadre global et la capacité à aborder ces questions critiques.De plus, l'ONUDC et l'OEA ont avancé stratégiquement le cadre pour soutenir les autorités haïtiennes dans la lutte contre la corruption et les crimes financiers. Cela a impliqué le développement et le déploiement d'outils et de modules de formation ciblés conçus pour améliorer les compétences et les connaissances des principaux acteurs du système judiciaire et des forces de l'ordre haïtiens. Ces efforts ne visent pas seulement à fournir un soutien immédiat, mais aussi à favoriser le renforcement des capacités et le renforcement institutionnel à long terme.

2024 Narrative: In partnership with the Superior Court of Justice (STJ), UNODC organized the ‘Regional Judicial Integrity Meeting for Latin America and the Caribbean’, a high-level regional meeting for judges and judiciaries from the region aiming at fostering regional collaboration and addressing common challenges (https://tinyurl.com/bde97c5k). The event gathered over 80 Chief Justice, Justices, members of the judiciary and experts from 21 countries as well as relevant judicial associations; it is an important milestone to the regional acceleration of the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC) implementation. In 2024, Brazil hosted the Expert Group Meeting (EGM) on Equal Access to Justice for All (https://tinyurl.com/4batavw4). The event brought together 41 experts nominated by 30 Member States across the Americas, Africa, Asia, and Europe, to share information on challenges, lessons learned, best practices and enabling factors needed to enhance the functioning of criminal justice systems to ensure equal access to justice for all.  The recommendations adopted at the meeting will be included in a report to the Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice (CCPCJ) at its 34th session in 2025. These recommendations aim to guide Member States and stakeholders in their efforts to implement UN General Assembly Resolution 78/227 – titled ‘Equal Access to Justice for All’ – and ensure no one is left behind. Other important events were ‘Talk with the Expert - Investigative Interviewing applied to non-cooperative suspects’ and the Seminar ‘Hearings and Police Interrogations: Generating Results, Ensuring Rights, and Protecting People’. The activities aimed at providing police forces with human-rights-based approaches to interviews conducted by law enforcement during investigations, prioritizing non-coercive communication. The first one trained circa 20 teachers and trainers to multiply the knowledge; the second gathered 50 people to broadly discuss the theme.

Given that these crimes disproportionately affect women and girls, the project implements several activities addressing this issue. 2022 Narrative: En abril de 2022, OIM Argentina elaboró un diagnóstico sobre las necesidades de los puestos fronterizos de Triple Frontera (Puerto Iguazú) y de Aguas Blancas-Bermejo con el fin de mejorar el registro y control migratorio mediante infraestructura tecnológica. En septiembre de 2022, se instaló una fibra óptica en Aguas Blancas que contribuyó a la reapertura de esa frontera para fortalecer la conectividad e impactar en el proceso de registro y control migratorio.  Además, se realizaron tres encuentros interministeriales en las ciudades de frontera: Puerto Iguazú y Aguas Blancas, con el fin de capacitar a los agentes migratorios, fuerzas de seguridad, equipos de protección provinciales, nacionales y fiscalías ordinarias y federales. Estos encuentros tuvieron por objeto la detección temprana de trata de personas en los pasos de frontera terrestres y rutas, la asistencia de los Equipos de Protección a las víctimas de trata de personas identificadas y el desarrollo del documento “Directrices y lineamientos básicos de investigación sobre trata de personas en el marco del Modelo Acusatorio”.
2023 Narrative: En julio de 2023 se constituyó la Plataforma Regional contra la Trata de Personas y el Tráfico Ilícito de Migrantes (PRETT), conformada por 10 países de América del Sur. Es un espacio de articulación y coordinación que funciona como marco para el intercambio de buenas prácticas, capacitaciones, iniciativas de cooperación con el propósito de mejorar la prevención, detección, persecución, judicialización, asistencia y protección a víctimas de trata de personas y tráfico ilícito de migrantes bajo un enfoque de género y derechos humanos. Además, el personal consular, los puntos focales en frontera, las fuerzas de seguridad y policías nacionales de Argentina, Brasil y Paraguay fortaleció sus capacidades en la lucha contra la trata de personas y el tráfico ilícito de migrantes en la Triple Frontera, en la Primera y Segunda Reunión Tripartita apoyadas por OIM. Allí se presentaron guías de abordaje del delito de trata de personas, se elaboraron recomendaciones para la lucha contra la trata de personas y el tráfico ilícito de migrantes, y se presentó la Ruta de Intervención en trata de personas de Paraguay y se desarrolló la propuesta de una Ruta de Intervención tripartita.  A su vez, se desarrolló el Encuentro Binacional de cooperación internacional para la firma de la Hoja de Ruta 2023 – 2024 entre Argentina y Bolivia para la prevención e investigación de la trata de personas y la asistencia y protección de las víctimas. Este documento está compuesto por 35 acciones conjuntas con foco en zonas de frontera, atención integral a víctimas y persecución e investigación del delito. El funcionariado de Argentina, Brasil, Paraguay, Ecuador, Colombia, Perú, Bolivia, El Salvador, organismos internacionales, personas de la academia, de OSCs y empresas de biometría e inteligencia artificial vieron fortalecidos sus conocimientos sobre gestión frontera en la Conferencia Regional "Identidad Legal, Biometría y la Gestión de Fronteras".
2024 Narrative: En 2024, la OIM Argentina brindó capacitaciones sobre detección temprana de victimas de trata de personas a funcionarios/as de la Dirección Nacional de MIgraciones y del Ministerio de Segurdad de la Nación. En estas actividades se enmarcaron en la actualización de la guia regional de detección temprana de trata de personas del MERCOSUR, realizada por el Programa Eurofront. Asimismo, la el equipo de coordinación regional del programa Eurofront, basado en la oficina de OIM Argentina tambien coordinó una capacitación con el formato de Formación de Formadores en Montevideo Uruguay, donde se capacitó a personal de DNM y Ministerio de seguridad para que puedan difundir hacia el interior de sus orgnismo el correcto uso de este instrumento (Guia de Deteccion Temprana MERCOSUR).La OIM Agentina, el marco del Programa EUROFRONT - Componente 2, realizó en la ciudad de La Paz, Bolivia, la segunda reunión plenaria de la Plataforma Regional contra la Trata de Personas y el Tráfico Ilícito de Migrantes (PRETT). Esta se realizó al final del primer año de existencia formal de la PRETT, donde se consolidaron las pautas de funcionamiento y se realizarón intercambio y sistematización de buenas practicas en materia de combate a la trata de personas y el tráfico ilícito de migrantes. Además, también se realizaron reuniones bilaterales entre los stakeholders de distintos paises para avanzar con la coordinación de acciones binacionales de combate a estos delitos. La PRETT es un espacio de articulación y coordinación entre 10 países de la región que funciona como marco para el intercambio de buenas prácticas, capacitaciones, iniciativas de cooperación con el propósito de mejorar la prevención, detección, persecución, judicialización, asistencia y protección a víctimas de trata de personas y tráfico ilícito de migrantes bajo un enfoque de género y derechos humanos. En este sentido, la PRETT se articula bajo tres ejes temáticos de trabajo: Prevención, detección y protección/asistencia a las víctimas; Persecución, investigación y judicialización de los responsables; Intercambio de información sobre tendencias regionales y bi-regionales sobre dinámicas de movilidad humana, en vinculación con nuevas modalidades delictivas trasnacionales. La reunión de Buenos Aires contó con la participación de las 10 delegaciones que consensuaron sobre las Pautas de Funcionamiento de la Plataforma y acordaron la elaboración del 1er Plan de Acción regional. Este mecanismo, junto a las acciones desarrolladas en el Plan de acción contribuirán a otorgarle mayor trascendencia a la articulación regional y al diálogo trasnacional, tanto para promover y agilizar los mecanismos de coordinación para la protección de las víctimas identificadas, como para fortalecer y visibilizar las herramientas de combate contra las organizaciones criminales.

Description:
UNODC’s Global Programme on Cybercrime is designed to respond flexibly to identified needs in developing countries by supporting Member States to prevent and combat cybercrime in a holistic manner.  The key objectives of this programme are:
•	Increased efficiency and effectiveness in the investigation, prosecution and adjudication of cybercrime, especially online child sexual exploitation and abuse, within a strong human-rights framework;
•	Efficient and effective long-term whole-of-government response to cybercrime, including national coordination, data collection and effective legal frameworks, leading to a sustainable response and greater deterrence;
•	Strengthened national and international communication between government, law enforcement and the private sector with increased public knowledge of cybercrime risks.

In 2022, UNODC launched the Project “Strengthening Trinidad and Tobago capacities to effectively prevent and counter online child sexual abuse and exploitation and related crimes” under the Global Cybercrime Project of UNODC. This project is funded by the Government of Canada and will be implemented until December 2024. The project aims to enhance the capacity of Trinidad and Tobago to identify, investigate, prosecute, adjudicate and prevent online child sexual exploitation and trafficking in persons facilitated by information and communications technologies.
Capacity building includes:
•	Cybercrime and digital evidence basics, proactive online investigations: using specialized platforms, such as CPS or ICACCOPS, to detect in real time the distribution of online child sexual exploitation material;
•	Train the trainer workshop in reactive online investigations: using platforms, such as the CyberTipline reporting mechanism, to receive reports from foreign technology companies on cases of online child sexual exploitation;
•	Open-source intelligence applied in investigating online child sexual abuse and exploitation and related crimes;
•	Identifying and handling digital evidence;
•	Criminal investigations involving the dark web, cryptocurrencies, for example.

Likewise, the Project will also facilitate the provision of specialized equipment for identifying, acquiring, analysing, and preserving digital evidence for the units responsible for investigating online child sexual abuse and exploitation and related crimes, as well as activities to support to Civil Society, prevention, and cooperation.

2023 Narrative: GMCP assists Member States in enhancing and coordinating their efforts against maritime and riverine crime. In Brazil, GMCP has three fronts of action. The first aims to strengthen Brazil’s interagency capacity on river and maritime control and the country's prosecutorial capacity to disrupt organized crime in the Amazon basin, including cross-border cooperation with Northern neighbouring countries. The second focuses on the Southern Tri-Border of Brazil (with Paraguay and Argentina), aiming to equip law enforcement agencies and criminal justice sectors with skills to detect, interdict, investigate and prosecute threats in rivers, especially trafficking. Thirdly, GMCP promotes cooperation between Brazil and West African countries.In 2023, GMCP held several capacity-building activities. At the beginning of the year, UNODC organized the International Exchange on Operations in the riverine domain, at the Center for Integration and Improvement in Environmental Policing (CIAPA), in Brazil, between Brazil, South Africa, Mozambique, and Tanzania.Regarding the cooperation between Brazil and Paraguay, GMCP held a Bilateral Tactical Training on Riverine Operations and an International Exchange on Tactical and Operational Approaches to Crime in the riverine domain. Both activities aimed to improve the coordination between Brazilian and Paraguayan efforts against riverine crime in the Tri-Border region.The project made significant efforts to promote South-South cooperation between Brazil and West African countries, namely Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, and Senegal. In November, it organized the Inter-institutional Dialogues to foster the exchange of information between intelligence agents from Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, Senegal, and Brazil. In the same month, GMCP held the first phase of the Diving Course for ship hull sweeping. The course aims to train public security agents in basic and advanced diving to enable them to take part in the second phase of the training, which will enable them to carry out public security dives and conduct ship hull scans. The training was organized in partnership with the Brazilian Federal Police and was attended by nationals from Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, Nigeria, and Senegal.
2024 Narrative: Under UNODC’s mandate to prevent drug trafficking and organized crime, in 2024, UNODC trained 26 people in Public Security Diving and Ship Hull Inspection to increase the national capacity for detecting illicit cargo as criminal organizations increase the practice of hiding illicit drugs in ship hulls (https://tinyurl.com/bdctjcmr, https://tinyurl.com/2mveawmk). In tandem, GMCP donated public safety diving equipment to the Brazilian Federal Police, to accelerate port inspection of ships headed to export.  Firstly, UNODC offered basic and advanced diving lessons to Brazilian federal police officers and officers from selected West African countries: Senegal, Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, and Nigeria, as this is necessary to undergo the specific course on ship hull inspection. Then, this year, the first cohort (06 people) underwent the hull inspection course. The second and third cohorts started the diving training in 2024 and are expected to learn hull inspection in 2025. In 2024, Brazilian divers intercepted half a ton of cocaine in ship hulls at the Santos Port. Investing in South-South Cooperation, UNODC held tripartite meetings to address illicit flows, contraband, and transnational organized crime via river routes: two sessions between Brazil, Paraguay, and Colombia regarding the Paraná-Paraguay Rivers, and two sessions among Brazil, Colombia, and Peru on the Amazon River Basin. In addition, UNODC held two training sessions under the River Operations Exchange Program for public security agents from Brazil, Colombia, Peru, and Mozambique in conducting river and riverine operations in the Amazon region, held at the Center for Integration and Improvement in Environmental Police. As a result of the Paraná-Paraguay Rivers talks, UNODC will invest in operational training for river operations to address drug trafficking and illicit flows. In the northern area, the focus was on the exchange of best practices, the practical application of international policies, and the technical review of cooperation memoranda between the countries. Additionally, UNODC held a workshop on multivariate analysis methodologies in Quantum Geographic Information System (QGIS), to promote the use of spatial analysis tools to support law enforcement interventions in the fight against organized crime in the triple border region between Brazil, Colombia, and Peru.

2023 Narrative: Project PRIS-COOP project focuses on addressing challenges posed by Transnational Criminal Organizations (TCOs) in Brazil and bordering countries. It divides itself into two main objectives: the first aim is to enhance prison management in Brazil and Paraguay, with a focus on the challenges posed by organized crime in prisons and on promoting cooperation between both countries. The second aim is to promote cooperation between Brazil, Peru and Colombia in combatting transnational organized crime in the Amazon region.One of the project’s main focuses is capacity-building: in Brazil, 344 prison agents received training, with an average improvement of 60,1% in their knowledge, based on pre- and post-training testing. It also promoted South-South cooperation between Brazil and Paraguay, resulting in 235 Paraguayan officers participating in training sessions conducted by Brazilian experts. In Paraguay, one of the activities was a Training of Trainers (ToT) in Prison Matters; by December 2023, these instructors had trained an additional 373 prison officers.PRIS-COOP organized several capacity-building and policy-focused activities. In Brazil, the project promoted seven (07) training sessions in partnership with the National Secretariat of Penal Policies (SENAPPEN). The project focused on strengthening state-level capacities in prison intelligence, training prison unit directors at the state and federal levels on dynamic security and enhancing the capacities of instructors of the National School for Criminal Services of SENAPPEN. In Paraguay, UNODC facilitated the organization of three (03) training sessions in partnership with Brazilian government agencies at the federal and state levels. The first course, in April, was on prison procedures and routines for the students at the Higher Technical Penitentiary Institute (ITSP) of Paraguay; then, in October, PRIS-COOP held a Training of Trainers on the theme. The third activity was aimed at prison unit Directors, to bolster leadership skills.  Additionally, PRIS-COOP supported four (04) international workshops to promote prison cooperation and police cooperation to address transnational organized crime within and outside prison settings. In parallel, UNODC worked to support Brazil and Paraguay in the theme of the classification of prisoners. In Paraguay, PRIS-COOP supported the development of general guidelines and an action plan for the development of a national classification system.In Brazil, UNODC was appointed as an official member of the National Technical Working Group to elaborate a National Standard on the Classification of Prisoners of the National Secretariat of Penitentiary Policies. The group will propose parameters for the implementation and operationalization of classification by the Brazilian states. UNODC was also invited to support the training of personnel on the SENAPPEN-supported pilot project on the classification of prisoners in Rio Grande do Norte, a Brazilian state which suffered a series of attacks against public buildings, businesses, public and private vehicles by prison-based organized groups in early 2023.
2024 Narrative: Under UNODC’s mandate to safeguard and implement The United Nations Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, also known as the Nelson Mandela Rules, and in line with the United Nations System Common Position on Incarceration, over 4,100 prisoners underwent classification interviews in three Brazilian states with UNODC support. In Amapá, the entire prison population (3,317 people) was interviewed by nurses, psychologists, and social workers to identify individual needs (https://tinyurl.com/34kmkcz7). Classification is highlighted in both abovementioned documents as imperative in promoting the resocialization of prisoners, guaranteeing prisoners’ rights – especially to access basic services, work, and education – and improving security for prisoners and prison staff alike. After the initial interviews, each state must advance in 2025 in drafting Individualized Sentence Plans that will contain each prisoner’s personal plan in view of access to education, work, health needs, and more. In 2024, in order to promote best practices in humane prison management, UNODC promoted the Workshop ‘Individualizing Sentences: Implementation of the Classification of Prisoners’ and the First International Seminar on Prison Intelligence (https://tinyurl.com/3xu93rmz); overall, 236 people participated in both events in total. Additionally, the office translated the UN System Common Position on Incarceration. In 2024, UNODC trained 778 penal police officers, prison officers, and other law enforcement agents from Brazil, Paraguay, Peru, and Colombia on prison management – especially prisoner classification, prison intelligence, and operational protocols. 276 Brazilian penal police and other law enforcement officers were trained on prison intelligence topics(https://tinyurl.com/mpn2mtuc, https://tinyurl.com/488883sn).In Paraguay, 260 prison staff were trained in prison procedures and basic intelligence. Finally, six prison officers from Colombia and Peru participated in a training on prison intelligence held in the north of Brazil.

2023 Narrative: From 12 to 20 January 2023, the naval exercise "Event Horizon" was held with the participation of the Armed Forces of the Dominican Republic, the coast guard of the Jamaica Defense Force and the Royal Bahamas Defense Force. The exercise aimed to strengthen coordination, camaraderie and combined/joint planning of operations against transnational organized crime in the maritime domain, search and rescue and humanitarian aid. In the scope of research, the project produced two main publications: (a) the “Qualitative Research on HIV Prevention for Women who Use Drugs with beneficiaries of ‘Programa Atitude’ in Recife and Caruaru”, and (b) the “Study on Causalities of Crime and Violence”.The first of the two studies evaluated the qualitative impact of the Programme for Integral Attention to People who Use Drugs and Respective Families (Programa Atitude) on its beneficiaries and issued recommendations for its improvement. A diverse group of 25 youths were trained to act as multipliers of the 2030 Agenda in their respective communities. They are now part of the National Youth Ambassadors Network, with the role of acting as spokespeople in national and international forums to promote policies for violence prevention, the promotion of peace, the search for fairer societies and sustainable development.One of the newly trained Youth Ambassadors told UNODC that "The Youth Ambassadors Program connects my restlessness with what I believe in: education and the power of youth. UNODC facilitated consultative sessions with 21 Youth Ambassadors to draft the National Plan to Safeguard Children and Adolescents from Violence, Drugs and Crime. Project Pernambuco further planned the construction of a State Drug Plan for Pernambuco in close consultation with the Executive Secretariat for Articulation and Social Prevention of Crime and Violence (SEAPREV) and the Executive Secretariat for Drug Policy (SEPOD).

Project: Combating Transnational Conservation Crimes in the Amazon (ECOS).
Actual start date: 01/03/2021.

This project aims to improve regional cooperation and capacity of enforcement and justice system actors to detect, interdict, investigate and prosecute transnational conservation crimes (TCCs) in the Amazon. To reach that, it focuses on (a) improving information exchange and regional cooperation between the Amazon countries, and (b) enhancing the capacity of enforcement and justice system actors to respond to TCCs. It acts on four main axis: forest crimes, wildlife trafficking, illegal fishing, and minerals-related crimes. It is implemented under the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime and in line with the Global Programme on Crimes that Affect the Environment.

2023 Narrative: This project aims to improve regional cooperation and the capacity of enforcement and justice system actors to detect, interdict, investigate and prosecute transnational conservation crimes (TCCs) in the Amazon in four main axes: forest crimes, wildlife trafficking, illegal fishing, and minerals-related crimes. To reach that, it focuses on (a) improving information exchange and regional cooperation between the Amazon countries, and (b) enhancing the capacity of enforcement and justice system actors to respond to TCCs. In 2023, in the scope of ECOS’ action on forest crimes, UNODC conducted a study on the creation of images and near-infrared spectra databases of 15 key species of native wood in national and international trade and/or listed in the appendices of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).The database will be used to improve algorithms applied in timber identification, with the goal creating of a tool for use in the field by law enforcement and environmental inspection agents. Such a tool would strengthen the response of these institutions in combatting illegal logging, while also contributing to the construction of more robust evidence for criminal investigations related to environmental crimes.UNODC and the Brazilian Forestry Service plan to launch an application in late 2024 based on the final algorithm. Project ECOS held the Regional Workshop for the Advancement of Timber Identification Field Techniques at the Rio de Janeiro Botanical Garden in November 2023 to present the preliminary results of the research and to strengthen inter-institutional work in the area.In the scope of minerals-related crimes, ECOS also held in Brasilia the 7th Informal Law Enforcement Network Meeting on Minerals-Related Crimes in cooperation with the World Customs Organization, the Government of France, USAID, and the European Union. The meeting connected relevant government officials and non-governmental organizations to strengthen information exchange related to the production and trade of mineral resources, including precious metals and stones.Additionally, the UNODC projects ECOS and Tapajós organized in Brasilia the first International Conference on Mercury Trafficking, in partnership with the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change. The conference had the objective of discussing emerging trends and challenges related to illicit mercury trafficking and gathered representatives from the Federal Government, security forces, environmental inspection agencies, embassies, the Public Prosecutor’s Office and civil society.Finally, within the fronts of action of wildlife trafficking and illegal fishing, UNODC organized the Indicator Framework Exercise of the International Consortium on Combating Wildlife Crime (ICCWC) in November in Brasília. The activity, held in partnership with the Ministry of the Environment, aimed to enable federal and state environmental and law enforcement agencies to self-assess the country’s response to crimes against fauna.
2024 Narrative: In 2024, under the framework of the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime (UNTOC) and UNODC’s Global Programme on Crimes that Affect the Environment, UNODC and the Brazilian Institute for the Environment and Renewable Natural Resources (IBAMA) launched Normative Instruction 28 of 11 December 2024 to protect four endangered wood genera from illegal exploration and trade (https://tinyurl.com/5dcxsyfv). The genera, which include famous trees such as Ipê, Cumaru, and Cedro-rosa, are included in the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).  Following a multi-stakeholder diagnosis of Brazilian normative on crimes against wildlife, UNODC launched the ‘Country Report: ICCWC Indicator Framework for Combating Crime against Wildlife’ in partnership with the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change (MMA) in 2023. Now, UNODC is supporting IBAMA in drafting the National Action Plan for the Prevention and Combat of Wildlife Crimes in consultation with relevant partners (https://tinyurl.com/mpw5vs3e).  Over 2024, project ECOS trained 119 people. 55 representatives from Brazil and other 10 South American countries were trained in Basic Intelligence for Environmental Surveillance (https://tinyurl.com/zc3wa244), and 21 Brazilians were trained in Shark Finn Identification (https://tinyurl.com/4jv8ud5e). Over 350 people attended the launch of the normative on endangered genera on-site or online during the “Ipê and Cumaru Week” promoted by UNODC and IBAMA. After the launching event, 43 IBAMA professionals were trained on how to apply the new norm. The Statement on Non-Prejudicial Exploitation, the founding part of the regulation, was built with the participation of more than 120 professionals.  UNODC is leading the development of two portable timber identification tools: one based on imaging and another on near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS); early in the year, both techniques showed promising results in the field (https://tinyurl.com/9x6vmcds). In addition, ECOS is leading the advancement of the Fisheries Origin Control System.

Description:
As outlined in the UNODC Strategic Vision for Latin America and the Caribbean, a more harmonized approach to continue supporting Member States on the implementation of specialized cross-border approaches that have demonstrated positive results on detection and interdiction of illegal Trafficking. 
AIRCOP is a  multi agency project based on the cooperation between  UNODC,  INTERPOL and  the World Customs Organisations (WCO) that aims at  strengthening the capacities of participating  international airports in Africa, Latin America, the Caribbean and the Middle East to  detect and intercept drugs, other illicit goods (including firearms, their parts and ammunition) and high-risk passengers (including victims of trafficking in persons and foreign terrorist fighters) in origin, transit and destination countries with the overall objective of  disrupting the illegal criminal networks. 
The increased capacity and knowledge of trained personnel has led to the expansion of the project scope to cover the multiple  threats targeting airports, including all illicit drugs, illicit goods (such as wildlife, counterfeit medicines or weapons) and, as of late, terrorism and trafficking in persons.
In 2022, UNODC signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the Government of Trinidad and Tobago for the implementation of the AIRCOP Programme at the Piarco International Airport in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad and Tobago. To date, 8 vetted officers from the Trinidad and Tobago Police Service (TTPS), the Immigration Department, the Customs Agency have been assigned to form the AIRCOP Task Force.
AIRCOP provides a range of standard and specialized training and mentoring activities, tailored tonational and regional needs. Topics covered include intelligence collection and sharing, targeting, search techniques, counterfeit documents, behavioral analysis, use ofl aw enforcement databases, secure communication procedures and post-seizure investigations, as well as specific thematic issues.
In 2022, UNODC facilitated training for the AIRCOP Task Force in the following areas:
-	AIRCOP Introductory Training
-	AIRCOP Training on Integrity in Law Enforcement
-	AIRCOP Training on Gender and Human Rights in Law Enforcement
-	Specialized Training on the Safe Handling of Synthetic Opiods, use of Raman Drug Testing Devices and Drug Precursor Kits
-	Specialized Training on Intelligence and Data (API and Passenger data)
-	Specialized Training on the Use of the WCO CENComm Platform
-	Exchange of Best Practices amongst AIRCOP JAITFs in Barbados, Jamaica and Trinidad and Tobago
Likewise, retrofitting and equipping of the AIRCOP working room was also carried out in 2022. One Raman Drug Testing Device was delivered to the AIRCOP Team for the Identification and Detection of Illicit Substances.

Sub-Output: Global Maritime Crime Programme (Programa Mundial contra la Delincuencia Maritima)
Description:
El GMCP se estableció en 2010, se creó inicialmente para abordar la piratería en el Cuerno de África. Con el tiempo, se expandió para cubrir una gama más amplia de delitos marítimos a nivel mundial. Su mandato es apoyar a los estados miembros en la lucha contra el crimen organizado marítimo, fortalecer la cooperación y desarrollar la capacidad de la ley en la aplicación. Implementado por la UNODC, el GMCP está presente en 90 países de América Latina y el Caribe, África, Asia, Europa y Oceanía.

Los delitos marítimos combatidos por el GMCP incluyen amenazas químicas, biológicas, radiológicas y nucleares; tráfico de armas de fuego; narcotráfico; trata de personas y contrabando de migrantes; delitos en el sector pesquero; y delitos ambientales.
